folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS-3)
display_name: Conceptual standard score
description:
Domain from the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System, 3rd Ed. (ABAS-3). The ABAS-3 is a rating scale useful for assessing skills of daily living in individuals with developmental delays, autism spectrum disorder, intellectual disability, learning disabilities, neuropsychological disorders, and sensory or physical impairments. The Conceptual domain standard score summarizes performance across the Communication, Functional Academics, and Self-Direction skill areas. Standard score range (higher is better): 1) Extremely low: <=70; 2) Low: 71 to 79; 3) Below average: 80 to 89; 4) Average: 90 to 109; 5) Above average: 110 to 119; 6) High: >=120. [Harrison P, Oakland T. Manual for the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System, 3rd Edition. San Antonio Harcourt Assessment, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/5)

[Search for all ABAS variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=abas)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS-3)
display_name: General Adaptive Composite standard score
description:
Summary score for the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System, 3rd Ed. (ABAS-3). The ABAS-3 is a rating scale useful for assessing skills of daily living in individuals with developmental delays, autism spectrum disorder, intellectual disability, learning disabilities, neuropsychological disorders, and sensory or physical impairments. The General Adaptive Composite (GAC) summarizes performance across all adaptive skill areas excluding Work. Standard score range (higher is better): 1) Extremely low: <=70; 2) Low: 71 to 79; 3) Below average: 80 to 89; 4) Average: 90 to 109; 5) Above average: 110 to 119; 6) High: >=120. [Harrison P, Oakland T. Manual for the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System, 3rd Edition. San Antonio Harcourt Assessment, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/5)

[Search for all ABAS variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=abas)

folder: General Health and Mood/Composite Asthma Severity Index (CASI)
display_name: Composite asthma severity index score (range: 0-15)
description:
Total composite score for Composite Asthma Severity Index (CASI). The compsite score is the sum of all four subscales (range 0 to 15), while higher score indicates higher asthma severity . [Wildfire JJ, Gergen PJ, Sorkness CA, et al. 2012 (PubMed ID: 22244599)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22244599/)

[Search for all CASI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=casi)

display_name: Daytime symptoms score (range: 0-3)
description:
Subscore for Composite Asthma Severity Index (CASI) daytime asthma symptom assessment. The subscore is based on the highest point value from CASI daytime asthma symptom assessment items (range 0 to 3). [Wildfire JJ, Gergen PJ, Sorkness CA, et al. 2012 (PubMed ID: 22244599)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22244599/)

folder: General Health and Mood/Composite Asthma Severity Index (CASI)
display_name: Exacerbation score (0, 2, 4, 6)
description:
Subscore for Composite Asthma Severity Index (CASI) exacerbation assessment. Score 2 points for each systemic corticosteroid burst recorded in the first item from the exacerbation assessment, and 2 additional points for each associated hospitalization. Range of values (0, 2,4,6). [Wildfire JJ, Gergen PJ, Sorkness CA, et al. 2012 (PubMed ID: 22244599)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22244599/)

[Search for all CASI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=casi)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Second Edition Behavior Regulation (BRI) index raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Behavior Regulation Index (BRI) captures the adolescent’s ability to regulate and monitor behavior effectively. It is composed of the Inhibit (control impulses; appropriately stop own behavior at the proper time) and Self-Monitor scales (keep track of the effect of own behavior on others). [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Second Edition Behavior Regulation (BRI) index T score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Behavior Regulation Index (BRI) captures the adolescent’s ability to regulate and monitor behavior effectively. It is composed of the Inhibit (control impulses; appropriately stop own behavior at the proper time) and Self-Monitor scales (keep track of the effect of own behavior on others). T scores from 60 to 64 are considered mildly elevated, and T scores from 65 to 69 are considered potentially clinically elevated. T scores at or above 70 are considered clinically elevated. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Second Edition Cognitive Regulation (CRI) index raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Cognitive Regulation Index (CRI) reflects the adolescent’s ability to control and manage cognitive processes and to problem solve effectively. It is composed of the Initiate (begin a task or activity; independently generate ideas), Working Memory (hold information in mind for the purpose of completing a task; stay with, or stick to, an activity), Plan/Organize (anticipate future events; set goals; develop appropriate steps ahead of time to carry out an associated task or action; carry out tasks in a systematic manner; understand an communicate main ideas or key concepts), Task-Monitor (check work; assess performance during or after finishing a task to ensure attainment of goal), and Organization of Materials (keep work space, play areas and materials in an orderly manner) scales and relates directly to the ability to actively problem solve in a variety of contexts and to complete tasks such as schoolwork. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)/Teacher's Form
display_name: Second Edition Cognitive Regulation (CRI) index T score (teacher-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Cognitive Regulation Index (CRI) reflects the adolescent’s ability to control and manage cognitive processes and to problem solve effectively. It is composed of the Initiate (begin a task or activity; independently generate ideas), Working Memory (hold information in mind for the purpose of completing a task; stay with, or stick to, an activity), Plan/Organize (anticipate future events; set goals; develop appropriate steps ahead of time to carry out an associated task or action; carry out tasks in a systematic manner; understand an communicate main ideas or key concepts), Task-Monitor (check work; assess performance during or after finishing a task to ensure attainment of goal), and Organization of Materials (keep work space, play areas and materials in an orderly manner) scales and relates directly to the ability to actively problem solve in a variety of contexts and to complete tasks such as schoolwork. T scores from 60 to 64 are considered mildly elevated, and T scores from 65 to 69 are considered potentially clinically elevated. T scores at or above 70 are considered clinically elevated. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

The Emotional Control scale measures the impact of executive function difficulties on emotional expression and assesses a child’s ability to modulate or control his emotional responses. The Emergent Metacognition Index (EMI) reflects a child’s ability to sustain ideas and activities in working memory and to plan and organize problem-solving approaches. folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Second Edition Emotion Regulation (ERI) index raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Emotion Regulation Index (ERI) represents the adolescent’s ability to regulate emotional responses and to shift set or adjust to changes in environment, people, plans, or demands. It is composed of the Shift (move freely from one situation, activity, or aspect of a problem to another as the situation demands; transition; solve problems flexibly) and Emotional Control (modulate emotional reponses appropriately) scales. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Preschool Version Flexibility (FI) index raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Flexibility Index (FI) represents a child’s ability to move flexibly among actions, responses, emotions, and behavior. description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Inconsistency scale indicate the extent to which similar BRIEF items were endorsed in an inconsistent manner relative to the combined normative and mixed clinical samples. folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Preschool Version Inhibitory self-control (ISC) index raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Inhibitory Self-Control Index (ISCI) represents a child’s ability to modulate actions, responses, emotions, and behavior via appropriate inhibitory control. The index is composed of the Inhibit (controls impulses and behavior; appropriately stops and modulates own behavior at the proper time or in the proper context) and Emotional Control (modulates emotional responses appropriately to situational demand or context) scales. [Gioia GA, Espy KA, Isquith PK. BRIEF-P Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function-Preschool Version, professional manual. Lutz, FL PAR; 2003.](https://www.parinc.com/Products?pkey=26)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

display_name: Negativity validity scale raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Negativity scale measures the extent to which the respondent answered selected BRIEF items in an unusually negative manner relative to the clinical sample. folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Plan/Organize scale raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Plan/Organize scale measures an adolescent’s ability to manage current and future-oriented task demands. The scale has two components: Plan (the ability to anticipate future events, to set goals, and to develop appropriate sequential steps ahead of time to carry out a task or activity) and Organize (the ability to bring order to information and to appreciate main ideas or key concepts when learning or communicating information). [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24) and [Gioia GA, Espy KA, Isquith PK. BRIEF-P Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function-Preschool Version, professional manual. Lutz, FL PAR; 2003.](https://www.parinc.com/Products?pkey=26)

Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

[Search for all BRIEF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=brief)

Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Shift scale T score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Shift scale assesses the ability to move freely from one situation, activity, or aspect of a problem to another as the circumstances demand. T scores from 60 to 64 are considered mildly elevated, and T scores from 65 to 69 are considered potentially clinically elevated. T scores at or above 70 are considered clinically elevated. folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Second Edition Self-Monitor scale raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Self-Monitor scale assesses awareness of the impact of one’s own behavior on other people and outcomes. It captures the degree to which an adolescent is aware of the effect that their behavior has on others and how it compares with standards or expectations for behavior. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF)
display_name: Second Edition Task-Monitor scale raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

The Task-Monitor scale assesses task-oriented monitoring or work-checking habits. The scale captures whether a child assesses their own performance during or shortly after finishing a task to ensure accuracy or appropriate attainment of a goal. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24)

display_name: Working Memory scale raw score (parent-completed)
description:
Caregivers completed age-appropriate versions of the BRIEF (BRIEF-Preschool Edition for ages 2-4 and age 5 years if in preschool, or the BRIEF 2nd Edition for ages 6-18 and age 5 years in kindergarten, PAR Inc, Lutz, Florida).The BRIEF instrument survey behaviours associated with executive functioning (ability to self-regulate, pay attention and organize in “real-world” situations) and provide clinically relevant information on a wide range of behaviours.

Working memory is the capacity to hold information actively in mind to enable adolescents to think about problems for a period of time, focus on a goal, and carry out multistep activities. [Gioia GA, Isquith PK, Guy SC, Kenworthy L. Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, 2nd Edition (BRIEF2). Odessa, FL Psychological Assessment Resources](https://www.parinc.com/Products/Pkey/24) and [Gioia GA, Espy KA, Isquith PK. display_name: Parent Report: Aggressive Behaviors percentile (%)
description:
The CBCL is a caregiver-completed assessments of child behaviour, used to detect behavioural and emotional problems in children and adolescents. The CBCL/1.5-5 (ASEBA, Burlington, VT) was administered to children 5 years or younger, while the CBCL/6-18 was administered to children 6 years or older. Reference: [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA preschool forms & profiles. Burlington, VT University of Vermont, Research Center for Children, Youth & Families; 2000](https://store.aseba.org/MANUAL-FOR-ASEBA-PRESCHOOL-FORMS-PROFILE/productinfo/605/) and [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA school-age forms & profiles. Burlington, VT University of Vermont, Research Center for Children, Youth & Families; 2001](https://store.aseba.org/MANUAL-FOR-THE-ASEBA-SCHOOL-AGE-FORMS-PROFILES/productinfo/505/)

[Search for all CBCL variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/abc/variables?search=cbcl)

The CBCL is a caregiver-completed assessments of child behaviour, used to detect behavioural and emotional problems in children and adolescents. The CBCL/1.5-5 (ASEBA, Burlington, VT) was administered to children 5 years or younger, while the CBCL/6-18 was administered to children 6 years or older. Reference: [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA preschool forms & profiles. Burlington, VT University of Vermont, Research Center for Children, Youth & Families; 2000](https://store.aseba.org/MANUAL-FOR-ASEBA-PRESCHOOL-FORMS-PROFILE/productinfo/605/) and [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA school-age forms & profiles. Burlington, VT University of Vermont, Research Center for Children, Youth & Families; 2001](https://store.aseba.org/MANUAL-FOR-THE-ASEBA-SCHOOL-AGE-FORMS-PROFILES/productinfo/505/)

[Search for all CBCL variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/abc/variables?search=cbcl)

display_name: Parent Report: Total Problems percentile (%)
description:
The CBCL is a caregiver-completed assessments of child behaviour, used to detect behavioural and emotional problems in children and adolescents. The CBCL/1.5-5 (ASEBA, Burlington, VT) was administered to children 5 years or younger, while the CBCL/6-18 was administered to children 6 years or older. The total score combines the internalizing and externalizing scores, summarizing of all specific behavior problem scales obtained from the pre-school or school age versions according to the child’s age. Higher T-scores indicate worse functioning, and a T-score of 65 or higher is considered clinically abnormal.

Reference: [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA preschool forms & profiles. Burlington, VT University of Vermont, Research Center for Children, Youth & Families; 2000](https://store.aseba.org/MANUAL-FOR-ASEBA-PRESCHOOL-FORMS-PROFILE/productinfo/605/) and [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA school-age forms & profiles. Burlington, VT University of Vermont, Research Center for Children, Youth & Families; 2001](https://store.aseba.org/MANUAL-FOR-THE-ASEBA-SCHOOL-AGE-FORMS-PROFILES/productinfo/505/)

[Search for all CBCL variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/abc/variables?search=cbcl)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Conners' Parent Rating Scale (CPRS)
display_name: Defiance/Aggression T score (parent-completed)
description:
Subscore from Conners 3rd Edition Short Form. The Conners 3rd Edition–Parent Short form [Conners 3–P(S)] is an assessment tool used to obtain the parent’s observations about the youth’s behavior. This instrument is designed to assess Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and its most common co-morbid problems in children and adolescents aged 6 to 18 years old. A T-score >= 65 is considered elevated (higher is worse). [Conner C. Conners 3rd edition manual. San Antonio Pearson; 2009](https://www.pearsonassessments.com/store/usassessments/en/Store/Professional-Assessments/Behavior/Conners-3rd-Edition/p/100000523.html)

[Search for all Conners 3 variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=conners3)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Conners' Teacher Rating Scale (CTRS)
display_name: Defiance/Aggression T score (teacher-completed)
description:
Subscore from Conners 3rd Edition Short Form. The Conners 3rd Edition – Teacher Short form [Conners 3–T(S)] is an assessment tool used to obtain the teacher’s observations about the student’s behavior in a school setting. This instrument is designed to assess Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and its most common co-morbid problems in children and adolescents aged 6 to 18 years old. A T-score >= 65 is considered elevated (higher is worse). [Conner C. Conners 3rd edition manual. San Antonio Pearson; 2009](https://www.pearsonassessments.com/store/usassessments/en/Store/Professional-Assessments/Behavior/Conners-3rd-Edition/p/100000523.html)

[Search for all Conners 3 variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=conners3)

This instrument is designed to assess Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and its most common co-morbid problems in children and adolescents aged 6 to 18 years old. A T-score >= 65 is considered elevated (higher is worse). [Conner C. Conners 3rd edition manual. San Antonio Pearson; 2009](https://www.pearsonassessments.com/store/usassessments/en/Store/Professional-Assessments/Behavior/Conners-3rd-Edition/p/100000523.html)

[Search for all Conners 3 variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=conners3)

display_name: Subject consented to share data publicly
Urinary cotinine value (ng/mL) (2017 analysis of 82 samples)
description: Retained as character formatted variable; 60/82 entries are "<50". Decision was made 3/7/2022 by SR to use 2022 values as the primary analytic variable.

display_name: Urinary cotinine lab comments
Urinary cotinine %CV (based on mean of replicates for individual samples) (2022 analysis)
description: Each patient urine aliquot was run in duplicate on the Cotinine ELISA kit. The %CV indicates the variation between the replicates. We usually like to see a % CV that is less than 20%. The Cotinine result is the mean value of the replicates.

display_name: Urinary cotinine value (ng/mL) (2022 analysis)
description: Primary analytic variable. Mean value of replicates (n=2). Note comment field for QC purposes.

folder: General Health and Mood/Family Assessment Device (FAD)
display_name: Calculated - FAD general functioning score (range: 1-4) - Sum of all items divided by 12. Items 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, and 11 reverse-coded.
description:
Summary score for the McMaster Family Assessment Device 12-item General Functioning Scale (FAD-GF), which is a unidimensional scale that evaluates a family's general pathology with six items on healthy and unhealthy family functioning, respectively. A score of 2.00 or above indicates problematic family functioning. The higher the score, the more problematic the family member perceives the family's overall functioning.[Byles J, Byrne C, et al. 1988 (PubMed ID: 3360100)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3360100/)

[Search for all FAD-GF variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=fadgf)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Go-No-Go Continuous Performance Task (GNG-CPT)
display_name: Total number of accurate trials (Sustained Attention/CPT Block)
description:
Component from the Go-No-Go Continuous Performance Task (GNG/CPT), which is a computer-based attention test developed for longitudinal studies of heterogenous samples of children ages 3 to 12 years. The primary test outcome from this test is d prime (d’) for the Continuous Performance Test trial block, a signal detectability parameter that assesses the child’s ability to correctly identify targets corrected for their response bias (higher is better). [Clark CAC, et al. 2023 (PubMed ID: 36633982)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36633982/)

[Search for all GNG/CPT variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=gngcpt)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Go-No-Go Continuous Performance Task (GNG-CPT)
display_name: Probability of missing fish when fish was presented (Sustained Attention/CPT Block)
description:
Component from the Go-No-Go Continuous Performance Task (GNG/CPT), which is a computer-based attention test developed for longitudinal studies of heterogenous samples of children ages 3 to 12 years. The primary test outcome from this test is d prime (d’) for the Continuous Performance Test trial block, a signal detectability parameter that assesses the child’s ability to correctly identify targets corrected for their response bias (higher is better). [Clark CAC, et al. 2023 (PubMed ID: 36633982)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36633982/)

display_name: Calculated - Total score (Range: 18-126)
description:
Summary score for the Obstructive Sleep Apnea-18 Quality of Life Questionnaire.Total OSA-18 survey scores are categorized into three groups based on the impact on the quality of life: minor (scores below 60), moderate (scores between 60 and 80) and major (scores above 80). [Franco RA et al., 2000 (PubMed ID: 10889473)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10889473/)

The physical health summary score is the sum of items answered in the physical functioning subscale score from the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL). A high score suggests better physical health. [Varni, Seid, and Rode 1999 (PubMed ID: 10024117)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10024117/)

display_name: Child Self-Report: Calculated - Psychosocial Health Summary Score
description:
The psychosocial health summary score is the sum of items answered in the emotional, social, and school functioning subscale score from the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL). A high score suggests better psychosocial health. [Varni, Seid, and Rode 1999 (PubMed ID: 10024117)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10024117/)

display_name: Child's dominant hand
description:
The National Institutes of Health Toolbox 9-Hole Pegboard Dexterity Test was used to assess fine motor control. Scores for this test are the times needed for the child to put each of nine pegs into the pegboard and then take them out using each hand, converted to age-adjusted scale scores (higher is worse). [National Institutes of Health 9-Hole Pegboard Dexterity Test](https://www.nihtoolbox.org/test/9-hole-pegboard-dexterity-test/)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Stress Index (PSI)
display_name: Difficult child (DC) scale percentile
description:
The Difficult Child (DC) subscale is based on 12 items from Parenting Stress Index Fourth Edition Short Form. DC subscore measures a parent's view of his/her child's temperament, defiance, non-compliance, and demandingness. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). Percentile between 16% to 84% = normal ranges, between 85% to 89%: high levels, greater than or equal to 90%: clinically significant. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

[Search for all PSI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=psi)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Stress Index (PSI)
display_name: Difficult child (DC) scale raw score
description:
The Difficult Child (DC) subscale is based on 12 items from Parenting Stress Index Fourth Edition Short Form. DC subscore measures a parent's view of his/her child's temperament, defiance, non-compliance, and demandingness. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). The total score is the sum of all five items ranging from 12 to 60. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

[Search for all PSI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=psi)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Stress Index (PSI)
display_name: Difficult child (DC) scale T score
description:
The Difficult Child (DC) subscale is based on 12 items from Parenting Stress Index Fourth Edition Short Form. DC subscore measures a parent's view of his/her child's temperament, defiance, non-compliance, and demandingness. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). T-scores generally range from 20 points to 100 points, and are considered the primary source for interpretation. T-scoring below 62: within normal limites; 63 to 64: borderline levels; 65 to 66: clinically significant level; above 67 (equivalent to percentile rank of 95% or higher): clinically severe levels. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

[Search for all PSI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=psi)

The Parent-Child Dysfunctional Interaction (PCDI) subscale assesses the extent to which a parent feels that his/her child is not meeting expectations and that interactions with the child are not reinforcing. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). Percentile between 16% to 84% = normal ranges, between 85% to 89%: high levels, greater than or equal to 90%: clinically significant. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Stress Index (PSI)
display_name: Parental distress (PD) scale percentile
description:
The Parental Distress (PD) subscale captures the level of distress resulting from personal factors such as depression or conflict with a partner and life restrictions due to a parent's perception of his or her child-rearing competence. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). Percentile between 16% to 84% = normal ranges, between 85% to 89%: high levels, greater than or equal to 90%: clinically significant. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

description:
The Parental Distress (PD) subscale captures the level of distress resulting from personal factors such as depression or conflict with a partner and life restrictions due to a parent's perception of his or her child-rearing competence. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). The total score is the sum of all five items ranging from 12 to 60. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

[Search for all PSI variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=psi)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Stress Index (PSI)
display_name: Parental distress (PD) scale T score
description:
The Parental Distress (PD) subscale captures the level of distress resulting from personal factors such as depression or conflict with a partner and life restrictions due to a parent's perception of his or her child-rearing competence. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). T-scores generally range from 20 points to 100 points, and are considered the primary source for interpretation. T-scoring below 62: within normal limites; 63 to 64: borderline levels; 65 to 66: clinically significant level; above 67 (equivalent to percentile rank of 95% or higher): clinically severe levels. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

display_name: Test date

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Stress Index (PSI)
display_name: Total stress scale percentile
description:
Total Stress(TS) score is based on all 36 items from Parenting Stress Index Fourth Edition Short Form. TS score examine the extent of stress in the parent–child relationship. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). Percentile between 16% to 84% = normal ranges of stress, between 85% to 89%: high levels of stress, greater than or equal to 90%: clinically significant stress. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

description:
Total Stress(TS) score is based on all 36 items from Parenting Stress Index Fourth Edition Short Form. TS score examine the extent of stress in the parent–child relationship. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). The total score is the sum of all five items ranging from 36 to 180. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

display_name: Total stress scale T score
description:
Total Stress(TS) score is based on all 36 items from Parenting Stress Index Fourth Edition Short Form. TS score examine the extent of stress in the parent–child relationship. Each item is scored on a 5 point scale (from 1-5). T-scores generally range from 20 points to 100 points, and are considered the primary source for interpretation. T-scoring below 62: within normal limites; 63 to 64: borderline levels; 65 to 66: clinically significant level; above 67 (equivalent to percentile rank of 95% or higher): clinically severe levels. [Abidin, R. R. (1995). Parenting Stress Index, Third Edition: Professional Manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources, Inc.](https://www.parinc.com/products/pkey/335)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Style and Dimensions Questionnaire (PSDQ)
display_name: Calculated - Authoritarian parent behavior (Range: 1-5)
description:
Authoritarian parent behavior summary score is based on 13 items from the Parenting Style Questionnaire Short Form (PSQ-SF). Each item is scored on a 5-point scale (from 1: never to 5: always). The total score is the sum of all 13 items divided by 13 (range 1 to 5). The highest calculated score indicates the preferred parently style. Authoritarian parent are high on acceptance and behavioral control, and low on psychological control, conceptualized as rational, warm, encouraging, and controlling in a way that promotes child autonomy. [Robinson, C. C., Mandleco, B., Olsen, S. F., & Hart, C. H. (1995). Authoritative, authoritarian, and permissive parenting practices: Development of a new measure. Psychological Reports, 77(3, Pt 1), 819–830.](https://doi.org/10.2466/pr0.1995.77.3.819)

[Search for all PSQ variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=psq)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Style and Dimensions Questionnaire (PSDQ)
display_name: Calculated - Authoritative parent behavior (range: 1-5)
description:
Authoritative parent behavior summary score is based on 13 items from the Parenting Style Questionnaire Short Form (PSQ-SF). Each item is scored on a 5-point scale (from 1: never to 5: always). The total score is the sum of all 13 items divided by 13 (range 1 to 5). The highest calculated score indicates the preferred parently style. Authoritarian parents are highly demanding and are often punitive and forceful in order to adhere to an absolute standard for behavior, conceptualized as rejecting and psychologically controlling. [Robinson, C. C., Mandleco, B., Olsen, S. F., & Hart, C. H. (1995). Authoritative, authoritarian, and permissive parenting practices: Development of a new measure. Psychological Reports, 77(3, Pt 1), 819–830.](https://doi.org/10.2466/pr0.1995.77.3.819)

[Search for all PSQ variables within this dataset](https://sleepdata.org/datasets/pats/variables?search=psq)

folder: General Health and Mood/Parenting Style and Dimensions Questionnaire (PSDQ)
display_name: Calculated - Permissive parent behavior (range: 1-5)
description:
Permissive parent behavior summary score is based on 4 items from the Parenting Style Questionnaire Short Form (PSQ-SF). Each item is scored on a 5-point scale (from 1: never to 5: always). The total score is the sum of all 4 items divided by 4 (range 1 to 5). The highest calculated score indicates the preferred parently style.Permissive parents promote psychological autonomy, are accepting, and exhibit lax behavioral control, conceptualized as indulgent and allowing children to make their own rules and decisions. [Robinson, C. C., Mandleco, B., Olsen, S. F., & Hart, C. H. (1995). Authoritative, authoritarian, and permissive parenting practices: Development of a new measure. Psychological Reports, 77(3, Pt 1), 819–830.](https://doi.org/10.2466/pr0.1995.77.3.819)

folder: General Health and Mood/Rapid Estimate of Adult Literacy in Medicine (REALM)
display_name: Calculated - REALM total score (range: 0-8)
description:
Summary score based on the 8 items for the Rapid Estimate of Adult Literacy in Medicine (REALM-R). The total score is the number of positively endorsed responses (i.e., pronouced correctly) to 8 medical words. Those with a score of 6 or less should be considered to be at risk for poor health literacy. [Bass PF 3rd, Wilson JF, Griffith CH. 2003 (PubMed ID: 14687263)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14687263/)

folder: Clinical Data/Neurobehavioral Assessment/Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)/Teacher Report Form (TRF)
display_name: Teacher Report: Aggressive Behaviors percentile (%)
description:
The CBCL is a caregiver-completed assessments of child behaviour, used to detect behavioural and emotional problems in children and adolescents. The CBCL/1.5-5 (ASEBA, Burlington, VT) was administered to children 5 years or younger, while the CBCL/6-18 was administered to children 6 years or older. Reference: [Achenbach TM, Rescorla LA. Manual for the ASEBA preschool forms & profiles.
